articles.headline: Lending a Hand to Banks, but Not to Nations
articles.snippet: Anxiety and mistrust on the Continent has led to fear that a country, not individual banks, could succumb to the liquidity crisis.
articles.abstract: Anxiety and mistrust on the Continent has led to fear that a country, not individual banks, could succumb to the liquidity crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Is it time for the European Central Bank to be as generous to countries as it is to banks?

articles.headline: In China, Car Brands Evoke an Unexpected Set of Stereotypes
articles.snippet: Car companies are grappling with an alternate universe of brand associations in China, where Buicks are status symbols and a Mercedes-Benz is the domain of the retiree.
articles.abstract: Car companies are grappling with an alternate universe of brand associations in China, where Buicks are status symbols and a Mercedes-Benz is the domain of the retiree.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Cars in the United States tend to come fully equipped with stereotypes. Ford Crown Victoria: law enforcement professional. Toyota Prius: upscale yuppie environmentalist. Hummer: gas-guzzling egotist.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Adam Century

articles.headline: Rushdie Runs Afoul of Web’s Real-Name Police
articles.snippet: Salman Rushdie’s fight over which name he is allowed to use on Facebook points to an increasingly vital debate over how people represent themselves on the Web.
articles.abstract: Salman Rushdie’s fight over which name he is allowed to use on Facebook points to an increasingly vital debate over how people represent themselves on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The writer Salman Rushdie hit Twitter on Monday morning with a flurry of exasperated posts. Facebook, he wrote, had deactivated his account, demanded proof of identity and then turned him into Ahmed Rushdie, which is how he is identified on his passport. He had never used his first name, Ahmed, he pointed out; the world knows him as Salman.

articles.headline: Site to Resell Music Files Has Critics
articles.snippet: ReDigi calls its new system a legal way for people to get rid of unwanted music files and buy others at a discount.
articles.abstract: ReDigi calls its new system a legal way for people to get rid of unwanted music files and buy others at a discount.
articles.lead_paragraph: Music fans looking to clear out some clutter can always try to sell their old CDs. But can someone resell an old digital music file of “Thriller” that’s languishing on a computer?

articles.headline: Whatever Court Rules, Major Changes in Health Care Likely to Last
articles.snippet: No matter what the Supreme Court decides, health care in America has changed in ways that will not be easily undone.
articles.abstract: No matter what the Supreme Court decides, health care in America has changed in ways that will not be easily undone.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Reed Abelson,  Gardiner Harris and  Robert Pear.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson, Gardiner Harris and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Qatar Wields an Outsize Influence in Arab Politics
articles.snippet: The tiny emirate’s intentions remain murky to its neighbors and even allies — some see a Napoleon complex, others an Islamist agenda.
articles.abstract: The tiny emirate’s intentions remain murky to its neighbors and even allies — some see a Napoleon complex, others an Islamist agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Qatar is smaller than Connecticut, and its native population, at 225,000, wouldn’t fill Cairo’s bigger neighborhoods. But for a country that inspires equal parts irritation and admiration, here is its résumé, so far, in the Arab revolts: It has proved decisive in isolating Syria’s leader, helped topple Libya’s, offered itself as a mediator in Yemen and counts Tunisia’s most powerful figure as a friend.

articles.headline: Sending a Harsh Message, U.S. Issues First Fine for Tarmac Delays
articles.snippet: The Department of Transportation is putting airlines on notice that they must not keep passengers waiting for more than three hours on the tarmac.
articles.abstract: The Department of Transportation is putting airlines on notice that they must not keep passengers waiting for more than three hours on the tarmac.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airlines are warned: no lengthy delays this winter.

articles.headline: Departures Unsettle Newsweek
articles.snippet: Three high-level departures are the latest sign that the Newsweek-Daily Beast merger is not going as planned.
articles.abstract: Three high-level departures are the latest sign that the Newsweek-Daily Beast merger is not going as planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newsweek was jolted by three high-level departures on Monday, a sign that the merger a year ago with The Daily Beast has left the magazine deeply unsettled.

articles.headline: Students Lose Zeal for Aiding Obama Again
articles.snippet: Even the president’s supporters said replicating the youthful energy that became a campaign hallmark would be unlikely.
articles.abstract: Even the president’s supporters said replicating the youthful energy that became a campaign hallmark would be unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — For much of the presidential election of 2008, Barack Obama’s campaign was Emma Guerrero’s life. She was one of a dozen volunteers who showed up at an Obama campaign office here every night, taking time from her studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, to be part of what she still remembers as the most exciting period of her life.

articles.headline: Signs of Broad Contagion in Europe as Growth Slows
articles.snippet: The growth was considered a last gasp before the debt crisis would drag the Continent into recession, as euro area output has already declined since September.
articles.abstract: The growth was considered a last gasp before the debt crisis would drag the Continent into recession, as euro area output has already declined since September.
articles.lead_paragraph: The borrowing costs of nations at the heart of Europe jumped sharply on Tuesday, the latest evidence of broader contagion across the Continent as economic growth stalled.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley, David Jolly and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Retailers See a Split in Behavior of Shoppers
articles.snippet: October retail sales exceeded analysts’ expectations, as affluent shoppers looked to the stock market and poor ones watched gas prices.
articles.abstract: October retail sales exceeded analysts’ expectations, as affluent shoppers looked to the stock market and poor ones watched gas prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Wal-Mart, shoppers cut back on staples like milk and meat that had price increases of a few cents. At Saks Fifth Avenue, they paid full price for shoes and designer fashions at a rate higher than before the recession.
